Well, I'd just say they simplified this language. They dropped i.e. genders and many complex inflections; all the stuff I'm handling in my primary language (not English) all day and am happy with. They improved English in the sense of making it easier to learn and master. Maybe you opine that language evolution is an endless simplification, beginning with silly Stone Age dudes that invented a complex system because they were so totally uneducated and lacking crucial language invention skills. However, others might point out that there is a certain critical point where further simplification of a language is - to put it mildly - not beneficial to anyone. So, how is progress?

To all the armchair linguists out there-

There's some truth but a lot of you are still wrong.

First, English is a Germanic language. It's a direct descendant of German.

Second, Proto-Indo-European isn't the mother tongue of all modern tongues. It's simply one prehistoric mother tongue out of many. We don't even know what it looks or reads like, but recent archaeological findings in Russia have uncovered a written language that MAY be a direct descendant of PIE.

Third, American English is just as valid. All dialects are valid, and there is no such thing as a "pure" language. Don't be prescriptivist. All languages are "bastardizations" of whatever came before them, and prescriptivist logic is self-defeating.

Fourth, American English IS closer to Shakespearean-era English than modern British English. It's also more "accent neutral" than British English, meaning it has a higher comprehension rate among low-proficiency English speakers/learners.

Fifth, have any of you guys even read Old-English? It's nearly mutually intelligible with Middle-German.

@tai69- Wrong across the board. Your historical pseudo-facts have nothing to do with the emergence of American English as a dialect. England being inhabited half a million years ago has nothing to do with the English language. Also, the word "English" comes from "Angeln" (where the word Anglo comes from) who were a group of Germanic people that emigrated to the British Isles. It was their isolation from the other Germanophones and exposure to French, Latin, and Spanish that caused the eventual emergence of English. There's a reason why they call English speakers "Anglophones".
